title: Ticket #2828: Persistent security session and collector health cache for tools
description:
New connections between Condor daemons are optimized by caching of security sessions. When High-Availability is in use, daemons also avoid collectors that have been unreachable in the recent past. The command-line tools don't see any of these benefits, since the information is only stored in memory. Each invocation of a tool needs to establish a new security session with each daemon it talks to and can spend a long time trying to contact a primary collector that's currently unreachable.

We give the command-line tools the same benefits the daemons have by writing out security session and collector health information to a persist cache file on disk. Subsequent invocations of the tools would read in this file and use any relevant information.

Argo Graphics has had their primary collector go down for prolonged periods of time, during which each tool invocation will spend a minute trying to talk to the dead machine before querying the secondary collector.
remarks:
2012-Feb-20 14:27:24 by matt:
FYI - https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=472320

2012-Feb-20 15:25:14 by bbockelm:
How do the tools express context? Where does the session get persisted? For example, if I do the following:

X509_USER_PROXY=/tmp/foo condor_status

then

X509_USER_PROXY=/tmp/bar condor_status

how will the tool determine if the persisted security session is still valid?

I think this is a lovely idea as an opt-in, especially for folks that invoke Condor programmatically (glideinWMS immediately comes to mind) and "know what they're doing". Having it turned on by default in a both safe and sane manner sounds very difficult.

2012-Feb-20 15:47:02 by jfrey:
The cached session information would have to include information about inputs that affected the establishment of the session, like the X509 credential used, if there was one.

It should certainly start life as opt-in. If we were to eventually enable it by default, that would be after a lot of testing.
